head.supplied: Clarendon, ¶ 2nd Oct. 1882 ¶ Highly esteemed Baron, ¶ ¶ Your kind letter of 20th last, together with a list ¶ of part of the Ardrossan ¶ Algae, reached me on the 29th, just as I returned from a ra...

div.p: RB MSS M39, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.
MS annotation by M: 'Keine Orchid' [not an orchid]. There is also an illegible annotation in another hand. Clarendon, 2ten Oct. 1882

Ihr freundlicher Brief vom 20tn post. nebst Liste eines Theils der Ardrossen Algen erreichte mich am 29tn, als ich eben von einer rapiden botanischen Exkursion zurückkehrte, die ich während meiner Ferien (nur eine Woche) nach Encounter Bay & der Murray Bridge unternommen hatte, und wobei ich eine Anzahl mir unbekannten Pflanzen erbeutete. Bitte, nehmen Sie freundlichst meinen besten Dank für Beide entgegen. Es ist mir ein grosse Ehre, dass sich der von Ihnen genannte grosse Algaloge sich die Mühe unterzogen hat, dieselben zu bestimmen. Vorher hat ich überhaupt nur ungefähr 8 Namen, meistens nur genetische, davon. Leider scheinen mir beim Umzuge ein Theil meinen Algen Spezimen verloren gegangen zu sein so dass ich für der meisten kein korrespondirendes Exemplar mehr habe. In Bezug auf die Grösse der Spezimen werde ich in Zukunft gewiss Ihrer Winke Folge leisten. Oefters lassen sich aber eben nur sehr kleinen u. vereinzelten auftreiben. Ihrem Wunsche, die Namen der für S.A. neuen Herrn Prof. Tate zu zusenden, ist sogleich Folge geleistet werden. Nächstens werde ich suchen Ihnen die hier an der Küste gesammelten Algen zuzusenden, sowie auch eine kleine Anzahl von Pt. Victor, Encounter Bay.
Die Pflanze, 877 habe ich bis jetzt noch irgends anderwärts gesehen. Was ist der Name derselben? Darf ich bitten? Nämlich um Ihre verehrte Photographie.
Herr Baron F. v. Mueller K.C.M.G. M. & Ph. D., F.R.S.

Gestern sandte ich an Ihre Adresse ein kleines Packet mit ein paar Copien eines meiner Pamphlette betreffend Prof. Ascherson’s Erklärungen der Fruktifikation von Cymodocea antarctica, u. damit ein frisches Exemplar des Micrantheum vom Square Waterhole in Blüthe, die Pflanze fand sich ziemlich häufig auf der Sandbergen des Scrubs bei Victor Harbour; Früchte der Drosera Whitackeri zum Vergleich mit der ferner Zeit gesandten von der blattlos blühenden Art, welche letzteren so weit ich dieselben vergleichen konnte, darin von erstern abweichen dass sie viel kleiner, schmäler, sowohl als kürzer sind, selbst bei vollkommenster Reife. Die Unterschiede beider Arten möchten sich also ungefähr folgendermassen stellen:

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Blattlose Drosera

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border-left: 0.5pt solid #000000; border-right: none; border-top: none; border-bottom: none;
cell.p: Dr Whitackeri

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Blüthen aus hartem trocknem Boden im April bis Mai vor den Blättern.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border-left: 0.5pt solid #000000; border-right: none; border-top: none; border-bottom: none;
cell.p: Blüthen nach der Bildung der Blätter im Juni bis Sept.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Blüthen mit schmäleren u. kürzeren Petalen.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border-left: 0.5pt solid #000000; border-right: none; border-top: none; border-bottom: none;
cell.p: Als Dr. Whitackeri

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Blüthen aussenhalb der pedicalen Blattrosette entspringend.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border-left: 0.5pt solid #000000; border-right: none; border-top: none; border-bottom: none;
cell.p: Blüthen im Mittelpunkte der Blattrosette gestellt.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Blatt oval an schmalen Stiele, beide deutlich von einander getrennt.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border-left: 0.5pt solid #000000; border-right: none; border-top: none; border-bottom: none;
cell.p: Blatt fast rund an breiten Stiele der fast unmerklich in ersteres übergeht nur durch den Mangel an Drüsenhaaren kenntlich.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Früchte lang im Verhältniss zur Dicke, letztere etwa ⅛ - 1/12 Zoll, u. 3-4 zellig.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border-left: 0.5pt solid #000000; border-right: none; border-top: none; border-bottom: none;
cell.p: Früchte globes, fast so dick als lang u. vielzellig (nach äusserem Anschien).

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Tuber weiss, ohne Purpursaft

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border-left: 0.5pt solid #000000; border-right: none; border-top: none; border-bottom: none;
cell.p: Tuber rothlich, mit stark gefärbtem Purpursafte.

div.p: Aussen obigen glaube ich auch eine Styphelia in frischem Zustande beigelegt zu haben, die als "Native Currant" hier bekannt ist. Dieselbe kommt im Murray Scrub an weniger Stellen zwischen Mallee vor.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p:
Your kind letter of 20th last, together with a list
Letter and list not found. of part of the Ardrossan
Yorke Peninsula, SA. Algae, reached me on the 29th, just as I returned from a rapid botanical excursion that I had undertaken during my holidays (only a week) to Encounter Bay and Murray Bridge
SA. and in which I secured a number of plants unknown to me . Please kindly accept my best thanks for both. It is a great honour to me that the great algologist named by you
J. Agardh. has taken the trouble to identify them. Previously I had really only about eight names, mostly only generic, of them. Unfortunately during the relocation, a part of my specimens of algae seem to have gone missing, so that for most of them I no longer have a corresponding specimen. In regard to the size of specimens, I'll certainly follow your suggestions in future. However, often only very small and single ones are cast up. Your wish to forward the names new for South Australia to Prof. Tate has been immediately carried out. Next time I'll seek to send you the algae collected on the coast here, as well as a small number from Port Victor, Encounter Bay.
Victor Harbor, SA.

Yesterday I sent a small packet to your address with a couple of copies of my pamphlet concerning Prof. Ascherson’s explanation of the fructification of Cymodocea antarctica
Tepper translated and read at the meeting of the Royal Society of South Australia on 13 June 1882, Ascherson (1882) on Cymodocea , a proof copy of which was almost certainly available; he had sent with O. Tepper to M, 18 June 1882, a copy of Ascherson's letter that formed the basis of the paper. The 'pamphlet' is much less likely to be a reprint of one of Tepper’s other two papers on Cymodocea that had been read substantially earlier (Tepper (1882), Tepper (1882b)). and with them a fresh specimen of Micrantheum from Square Waterhole in bloom. The plant is found rather commonly on the sand hills of the scrub at Victor Harbor. Fruits of Drosera whittackeri for comparison with the leafless flowering species sent previously, which latter, as far as I could compare it, differs from the former in that it is much smaller, narrower as well as shorter even at fullest maturity. Thus the differences of both species may be presented approximately as follows:

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Leafless Drosera

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border-left: 0.5pt solid #000000; border-right: none; border-top: none; border-bottom: none;
cell.p: D. whittackeri

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Flowers on hard, dry ground in April until May before the leaves.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border-left: 0.5pt solid #000000; border-right: none; border-top: none; border-bottom: none;
cell.p: Flowers after formation of leaves in June to September.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Flowers with narrower and shorter petals

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border-left: 0.5pt solid #000000; border-right: none; border-top: none; border-bottom: none;
cell.p: As D. whittackeri

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Flowers originating outside the pedicle leaf-rosette.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border-left: 0.5pt solid #000000; border-right: none; border-top: none; border-bottom: none;
cell.p: Flowers placed in middle of the leaf-rosette.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Leaf oval on narrow stalk, both distinctly separated from one another.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border-left: 0.5pt solid #000000; border-right: none; border-top: none; border-bottom: none;
cell.p: Leaf almost round on broad stem that passes imperceptibly into the former, distinguishable only by the lack of hair glands.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Fruits long in proportion to thickness, the latter about ⅛ - 1/12 of an inch and 3-4 celled.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border-left: 0.5pt solid #000000; border-right: none; border-top: none; border-bottom: none;
cell.p: Fruit globular, almost as thick as long and multicelled (according to external appearance).

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Tuber white without purple juice.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border-left: 0.5pt solid #000000; border-right: none; border-top: none; border-bottom: none;
cell.p: Tuber reddish, mit strongly coloured purple juice.

div.p: Apart from the above, I think I have also enclosed a Styphelia in fresh condition that is known as "Native Current" here. It occurs in the Murray Scrub at a few places between Mallee trees.

Until now I have never seen the plant 877 elsewhere. What is its name?
MEL 62244 is a specimen of Zieria veronicea subsp. veronicea bearing Tepper's collecting number 877. M had previously identified his specimens 159 and 58 as Zieria veronicea, (respectively, M to O. Tepper, October 1881 (in this edition as 81-10-00b), and M to O. Tepper, January 1882 (in this edition as 85-01-00)).
May I request your respected photograph?

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in; font-size: 10pt;
font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in; font-size: 10pt;
font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in; font-size: 10pt;

div.p: Baron F. v. Mueller K.C.M.G. M. & Ph. D., F.R.S.
